python_codes.linear_theory.calculate_solutionÂ¶

calculate_solution(eta, eta_H, eta_0, eta_B, Fr, max_z, Kappa=0.4, output='simple', **kwargs)[source]Â¶

Solve the system and apply the boundary conditions.

Parameters

  • eta (scalar, numpy.array) â vector of vertical non dimensional positions \(k z\) where to calculate the solutions.

  • eta_H (scalar, np.array) â Non dimensional boundary layer height \(k H\).

  • eta_0 (scalar, np.array) â Non dimensional hydrodyamic roughness \(k z_{0}\).

  • eta_B (scalar, np.array) â Non dimensional stratification length \(k L_{B}\).

  • Fr (scalar, np.array) â Froude number

  • max_z (scalar, np.array) â Maximum vertical position where the system is solved, and also where the boundary conditons are applied. Usually set to something slightly smaller than eta_H to avoid the very slow resolution close to the top of the boundary layer. Usefull when investigating the solution close to the bottom.

  • Kappa (float, optional) â Von KarmÃ n constant (the default is 0.4).

  • output (string, optional) â changes what returns the function (default is âsimpleâ).

Returns

If output is âsimpleâ, return an array with the solution in every vertical step specified by eta. If output is âfullâ, return a list whose elements are: - the array with the solution in every vertical step specified by eta. - the output of _solve_system. - the coefficients of the linear decomposition of the solution.

Return type

np.array, list
